issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops
Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw: I was expecting the simulation to run at maximum 1x realtime, possibly slower, and that the solution docker would get the largest AWS instance all for itself. If this is not the case, I am not sure what is expected from the teams participating.
content.html: I was expecting the simulation to run at maximum 1x realtime, possibly slower, and that the solution docker would get the largest AWS instance all for itself. If this is not the case, I am not sure what is expected from the teams participating.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
If you run more than one robot, it looks like it will be at or below 1x realtime even with Simple Tunnel 2.  I  did an experiment with Simple Tunnel 2 and it ran at ~1x realtime with 2 vehicles.  I removed all of my object identification processes / nodes to try and reduce the load and got my code running ~3x slower than on my local computer \(vs ~10x above with the object identification\).

‌
content.html:
If you run more than one robot, it looks like it will be at or below 1x realtime even with Simple Tunnel 2. I did an experiment with Simple Tunnel 2 and it ran at ~1x realtime with 2 vehicles. I removed all of my object identification processes / nodes to try and reduce the load and got my code running ~3x slower than on my local computer (vs ~10x above with the object identification).

‌

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
I did an experiment with 5 vehicles and Tunnel Practice 1.  It ran at ~1/7 of real time.  The control loop seemed to be running fast enough, but the vehicle did not take off.  \(#208\)

‌

content.raw: I can confirm that the performance of the solution container is not good. A function that needs on my local computer about 0.03 seconds simulation time needs about 0.6 seconds simulation time in cloudsim.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw: When I know it is deployed I will try some runs.  I have been limiting the realtime performance to slower than 1x by adding multiple robots and that has not resolved the issues.  What type of instance is the solution docker running on?
content.html: When I know it is deployed I will try some runs. I have been limiting the realtime performance to slower than 1x by adding multiple robots and that has not resolved the issues. What type of instance is the solution docker running on?

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw: We are using AWS g3s.xlarge. The specs are listed [here](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/g3/).
content.html: We are using AWS g3s.xlarge. The specs are listed here.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3031425478-image.png)
‌

How many of these instances are involved in one simulated run? Do I understand correctly [#!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim\_architecture](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture) that each robot controller gets its own instance of g3s.xlarge and there only the solution container and the bridge container are run? Is the performance impact of the bridge significant or is more or less the whole instance available for the controller? Do you know what vCPU is? They only say it is “based on Intel Xeon 2.7GHz”. Is the GPU shared in any way with any other code/customer or is it dedicated full time to the controller?
content.html:
‌

How many of these instances are involved in one simulated run? Do I understand correctly #!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture that each robot controller gets its own instance of g3s.xlarge and there only the solution container and the bridge container are run? Is the performance impact of the bridge significant or is more or less the whole instance available for the controller? Do you know what vCPU is? They only say it is “based on Intel Xeon 2.7GHz”. Is the GPU shared in any way with any other code/customer or is it dedicated full time to the controller?

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
This instance explains quite a bit of the performance problems.  The CPU is listed as a custom Xeon E5-2686 v4.  Two 16 or 18 core CPUs are present for a total of 32 cores / 64 threads running at 2.3-2.7GHz.  The g3s.xlarge instance gets 2 cores / 4 threads.  The other 14 cores/ 28 threads are running with other users.

Locally most people probably have 1.5 to 2x faster performance per core and 2x to 4x more cores/threads.

An easy solution to a good part of the performance issues would be to switch to the next tier up of g3s.  With the current tier most solutions are thread/CPU starved.

 

‌
content.html:
This instance explains quite a bit of the performance problems. The CPU is listed as a custom Xeon E5-2686 v4. Two 16 or 18 core CPUs are present for a total of 32 cores / 64 threads running at 2.3-2.7GHz. The g3s.xlarge instance gets 2 cores / 4 threads. The other 14 cores/ 28 threads are running with other users.

Locally most people probably have 1.5 to 2x faster performance per core and 2x to 4x more cores/threads.

An easy solution to a good part of the performance issues would be to switch to the next tier up of g3s. With the current tier most solutions are thread/CPU starved.

‌

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
The bridge is lightweight. It only converts messages from to/from ROS and Ignition.

Each robot gets its own g3 instance.

All AWS machines are virtualized, they indicate this with the `vCPU` name.

We choose the g3s.xlarge because it's similar to the nvidia tx2, which has 2 cores. I'll check to see if an upgrade is possible.
content.html:
The bridge is lightweight. It only converts messages from to/from ROS and Ignition.

Each robot gets its own g3 instance.

All AWS machines are virtualized, they indicate this with the vCPU name.

We choose the g3s.xlarge because it's similar to the nvidia tx2, which has 2 cores. I'll check to see if an upgrade is possible.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
1. There is the possibility of increasing instance size for future competitions.
2. There is also the possibility of using different instance sizes for each robot configuration. For example, a large UGV could potentially have a larger AWS instance.

Keep in mind that these are possibilities for future events. We are one week from the close of Tunnel Circuit, which means significant changes are unlikely in order to limit risk and promote fairness.
content.html:
1. There is the possibility of increasing instance size for future competitions.
  2. There is also the possibility of using different instance sizes for each robot configuration. For example, a large UGV could potentially have a larger AWS instance.

Keep in mind that these are possibilities for future events. We are one week from the close of Tunnel Circuit, which means significant changes are unlikely in order to limit risk and promote fairness.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw: My expectation was that if it ran locally in cloudsim it would run in the cloud in cloudsim.  It is disappointing to find out a week before that the contest that we were supposed to be targeting a slow 2 core processor.
content.html: My expectation was that if it ran locally in cloudsim it would run in the cloud in cloudsim. It is disappointing to find out a week before that the contest that we were supposed to be targeting a slow 2 core processor.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw:
@{557058:44b40072-c04b-41ae-ad09-376db9ebffa1} the [CloudSim Architecture documentation](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture) was posted back in July and indicates that  [AWS G3 EC2](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/web-cloudsim/src/default/k8-readme.md#markdown-header-we-are-using-the-following-amis) instances were going be used.

‌
content.html:
@GoRobotGo the CloudSim Architecture documentation was posted back in July and indicates that AWS G3 EC2 instances were going be used.

‌

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw: I will admit I missed that in the documentation.  A G3 instance ranges from 2 to 32 cores \(4 to 64 threads\).  So, this documentation would not have been enough to know that we needed to target a slow 2 core processor.  As I mentioned before, any of the other G3 instances would resolve most of the performance problems.
content.html: I will admit I missed that in the documentation. A G3 instance ranges from 2 to 32 cores (4 to 64 threads). So, this documentation would not have been enough to know that we needed to target a slow 2 core processor. As I mentioned before, any of the other G3 instances would resolve most of the performance problems.

issue.title: Cloudsim performance insufficient to run stable control loops

content.raw: We are in the process of bumping the cloud machine instance type to a g3.4xlarge, this is from the current g3s.xlarge. We are waiting on AWS to increase our EC2 availability limit. I'll follow up on this thread when the limit has been increased and we have updated cloudsim.
content.html: We are in the process of bumping the cloud machine instance type to a g3.4xlarge, this is from the current g3s.xlarge. We are waiting on AWS to increase our EC2 availability limit. I'll follow up on this thread when the limit has been increased and we have updated cloudsim.
